Did I not pule, and pine, entreat, and cry?
Pretend a sickness? threaten I would die,
If she not loved me? did I not act all
The frantic parts wherewith love does enthral
His rebell-subiects? Did I not look sad
If she but frowned; and, if she smiled, look glad?
I did; and took delight to be enchained
To her, hope said at last she might be gained.
Yet see the wheel of change! I now do scorn
Her tears, and now she thinks herself forlorn.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Pardon my intrusion sir, HistoriaMelancholico enters.
Hearing you were hurt lately in a fray,
has in her jealousy of love sent here
Some physic, to prevent a greater fear.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.l: She should have sent me poison, far from her
I count it so; yet let the messenger
Return our courteous gratitude. Begun. Exit Melancholico.
Lo, thus vexations never come alone;
Well, I won't love her; nay, I'll have her more
Henceforth; she plagues me worse than before.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Pardon once more, sir, here comes sent by her,
Medicus, servant to administer
The physic.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.l: — Why, I prithee know I lack
No physic, there 'tis, thou mayst carry't back.

sp.speaker: Sanguis.
sp.p: The gods forbid, sir, this is poison. Sanguis looks on the poison.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: — How!

sp.speaker: Sanguis.
sp.p: 'Tis poison, sir.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.l: — Why? it was sent but now
From my lovesick Historia.

sp.speaker: Sanguis.
sp.l: — So 't may be:
They've changed my master's physic.

lg.l: The treachery of women! well, conceal
The fact as yet; just time shall all reveal.
O women, witches, monsters, furies devils,
The impure extract of a world of evils;
Of the god's wisdom; and th' anomaly
From all that's good; I'll curse you all below
The centre, and, if I could, than further throw
Your cursed heads; and if any should gain
A place in heaven, I'll time 'em down again
To a worse ruin; yet methinks I hear
How astronomia whispers in mine ear,
And begs a pardon for them; well; to thee
I'll yield, thou standest above mortality.
Aspire, my gentle muse, inflame my breast;
Then thus my graceful love shall be expressed.
Her brow is like a brave heroic line,
That does a sacred majesty enshrine.
Her nose phaleuciac-like in comely sort
Ends in a trochee, or a long and short.
Her mouth is like a pretty dimeter;
Her eyebrows like a little-longer trimeter.
Her chin is an Adonic; and her tongue —
Her eyes, I may compare them unto two
Quick-turning dactyls, for their nimble view.
Her neck asclepiad-like turns round about
Behind, before a little bone stands out.
Her ribs like staves of sapphics do descend
Thither, which but to name were to offend.
Her arms like two iambics raised on high,
Do with her brow bear equal majesty.
Her legs like two straight spondees, keep a pace
Slow as two Scazons, but with stately grace.
Thanks to my muse; yet why do I admire
Her thus, whom I enjoy but by desire?
For more I never shall; this is my weight
Of grief, and this my preordained fate.
He takes up his lute.come, come, thou part of heaven, companion
Of all my woes and loves, thou that alone
Dost in the midst of sorrows yield relief,
And though not take away, make less my grief.
lg.stage: He plays on his lute, then leaves off, and speaks again.
lg.l: My dearest lute, Apoollo's best invention
Wherewith he does compose the wild dissension
Of our untuned desires, which would confound
Us quite, but that they break forth with a sound!
Sighs from our breasts are like sounds from thy womb,
Born dead, and buried in an aery tomb.
Sigh then to Cupid, tell him he's too blame
Not raising in my love a mutual flame.

div.stage: He plays on his lute, and leaving off, calls to his man

sp.speaker: Melancholico.
sp.p: Ho, Melancholico.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: — Here sir.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: — Begun.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Did you not call me sir?

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: — Sirrah, begone.
sp.stage: He plays a little on his lute, and then calls melancholico again.
sp.p: Ho, Melancholico.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: — Sir.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: Dance, I say, dance.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: — I can't.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.l: — Sirrah, dance that which I play.
sp.stage: He plays the antique on his lute, and melancholico dances, then abruptly leaving off, he speaks to him.
sp.l: Begun:Melancholico continues dancing. sirrah, begone.
sp.stage: He plays again on his lute, and suddenly leaving off, throws it away.
sp.l: — Away, away,
Charmer, enchanter, 'tis a truth to say,
Our bodies cast their shapes into the air,
And can appear when they are gone; so rare
Philosophers have held, and so I hold:
Pardon, great astronomia, I was bold,
Too-bold, I do confess, but my dim sight
Could not before behold thee though so bright.
But now mine eyes are cleared; on my bowed knee,
I ask a pardon of thy majesty.
Pardon thy poet, and vouchsafe this grace,He feigns astronomia to be present, falls on his knees, embraces and kisses the air: then rises.
That thy rich beauties he may thus embrace.
And now, dear love, add hereunto one kiss,
And than thou shalt in heaven my soul with bliss.
Maro, thy riddle's solved: I thus untie
The knot, which thou didst knit, men's wits to try.
Dic quibus in terris (Et reis mihi magnus Apollo)
Tres pateat coeli spatium (Non amplius) ulnas?
Maro, 'tis here; here's astronomia;
Here's heaven closed in those narrow limits; nay,
Here's deity, the object of all loves,
Enough to make a thousand heavens of Jove's.
See,He thinks he sees her ascending into heaven.see, how she ascends! mount, mount, great Queen
Of heaven, and in full lustre be thou seen
Mortality's amazement; see, she's gone
To mount yet higher to a stately throne,
Placed on the azure pavement of the stars,
Guarded by days, months, hours, then sees the wars
Of pigmy-mortals —. Enter melancholico.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: — Sir, here's Ethicus
Is come, and says he'd speak with you.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.l: — With us?
Admit him in. Exit Melancholico. Enter Ethicus.

sp.speaker: Ethicus.
sp.l: — Hay! scarce dressed yet! how so?

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.l: What? comes your froward age to chide us?

sp.speaker: Ethicus.
sp.l: — No.
But to invite you to a feast, myself your friend,
Desirous of your peace, to set an end
To your contentions with Grammaticus
And logicus, tonight do purpose thus
To make you friends.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.l: But —

sp.speaker: Ethicus.
sp.l: — Nay, no butts: be there.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Ethicus.
sp.l: — Why thanks. Welcome shall be your cheer.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.l: Well then, I'll in and dress me, and so come,
Yet better 〈◊〉 perchance you had my room. Exit poeta.

sp.p: 〈…〉 to deal with spirits?

〈…〉 ●ly a geometrician, it is lawful
for you to deal only with bodies: but if you will undertake our superior faculty, 'tis not only lawful, but most honourable; why sir, 'tis one of the greatest gifts of the gods to have command over spirits; but for the approbation of it, you may only look back unto the antiquity thereof, which is drawn from more than eight hundred years before the siege of Troy, in the time of Agonaces, and of the renowned Zoroaster a King of the Bactrians, who described the high mystery of this divine science in an hundred thousand verses; after these there flourished Jobeth, Toluscol, Zamolxis, whose admired fame was afterwards emulated by Almadal, Alchindus, and Hipocus Arabians: Apuscorus, Zaratus, and Cobares, Medians: Marmaridius, a Babylonian: Zarmocenidas, an Assyrian, Abbaris, an Hyperborean, Thesphetion, an Aethiopian, Arnuphis, an Egyptian, Theurgus, a Chaldean: with these I may recite Cambyses, Zamares, Charondas, Demogorgon, Gobrias, Arbatel, Apollonius, gog, Hostanes, Atyr, Choastes —

sp.speaker: Geometres
sp.p: Good sir, do not conjure.

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: No sir, these are nothing but the names of the sacred professors of this divine science.

sp.speaker: Geometres
sp.p: I but it may be sir, they had conjuring names.

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p:
Alas, sir! 'tis not so easy a matter to work effectually in our sacred science, as most men think it is, and as I will most manifestly declare unto you; for this is a rule, you must be first an absolute astrologian; upon which fundamental supposition I thus proceed: before you can obtain the knowledge of astrology, you must be a most grounded philosopher, a sound physician, and an exquisite mathematician; by the helps of which sciences you shall know the courses of the stars; the number of the orbs; your poles; the circles; the vertical and pedal points; the azimuth, or vertical circle; the Almucantarath or circles of altitude; the concentricity and excentricity of the orbs; the ascendent, and descendent knots, or syndesms, that cut the ecliptic; your orbs aequant, epicyclical, and deferent of the apogeum, and perigeum, or of the highest and lowest absis; the planetary aspects, or configurations, either right
as conjunction and opposition, or collateral as sextile, quadrate, and trine; the direct motion of the planets, their retrogradation and station; then sir, your astrology is either canonical for the influence of the stars, or thematical for the erection of a scheme of the heavens, wherein is to be known the order of the Domicils, and the inscription. Then there is your judiciary, which is either genethliacal, or Catholic instructing in predictions, either idiomatical or symptomatical; the eight and twenty mansions of the moon; the symbolisation of occult qualities in herbs, with the planets; signacles, pentacles, planetary suffumigations, unctions, pailters, rings, alligations, suspensions; the twelve scales of the numbers; the duodenary scale, either cabalistical or orphical; the characters, seals, and bands of spirits —

sp.speaker: Geometres
sp.p: You'll give me all this in writing sir; won't you?

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: Yes sir, yes. Then are there divers kinds of your magic, as necromancy, anthropomancy, gastromancy, cheiromancy, coscinomancy, —

sp.speaker: Geometres
sp.p: I pray, do you yourself know how many there are in all?

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: Sir, one and twenty. I'll begin them over again, if you will. Necromancy, anthropomancy —

sp.speaker: Geometres
sp.p: Nay, good sir hold, we have enough already: but I perceive you magicians have admirable memories to get hard words by heart; I marvel you do not turn dictionarie-makers: why? I warrant there's no hard word but you can tell the meaning on't: you'd put all their noses out of joint quite.

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p:
Ay, and put them out of their wits, if we list: but then, sir, to know the spirit of every day, and hour; his name, power, and legions under him, his form of appearing, whether like a dragon, or an horse, or a wolf, or a flame of fire; the region whence he comes; the gift he bestows, whether learning, riches, beauty; his name, his characters: these, these, are the wonders, the amazements of our spiritual science; spiritual I may justly call in, since every art receives an excellency from its object; and yet (Alas!)
I confess, I am but young in it yet, and have scarce served a 'prentice-ship in it, if it may be called a servitude, wherein there is such freeness, and evagation of spirit in such exquisite knowledge; nay, dominion over spirits.

sp.speaker: Geometres
sp.p: Young say you? marry, I think, you are absolutely grounded in it, that can know all these mysteries; ah, were it the will of the gods, I had but half of this skill, I'd give all that I have, and get more as I could; but can you do all these wonders?

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: Far stranger, far stranger; most amazing transformations; why, there was Apuleius so skilful in this art, that he turned himself into an ass, and Lucian was turned into an ass, before he studied it.

sp.speaker: Geometres
sp.p: O strange! but can a spirit give learning?

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: O, there was Hermolaus barbarus, when he studied philosophy, and less understood any place, he would call up a spirit to instruct him; so the famous Cardan's father carried one always in a ring on his finger; and Agrippa had his dog with a characterized collar.

sp.speaker: Geometres
sp.p: But can you by your art, tell me whether or no I shall have astronomia?

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: Any thing.

sp.speaker: Geometres
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: Why, I can do it by coscinomancy.

sp.speaker: Geometres
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: By the turning of a sieve.

sp.speaker: Geometres
sp.p: But I have heard, that's only for things stolen.

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: Ah, 'tis more general, and that you shall see; stay here, I'll but step forth. Exit Magus.

sp.speaker: Geometres
sp.p: Well, this is the man whom the heavens have ordained to make me happy; oh Venus, be favourable unto me, and I'll build thee a fairer temple than ever the Ephesians directed to Diana. Magus enters.

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p:
Come sir, here are shears and a sieve; I must fasten the shears? now do as I bid you; hold up the side of the shears with your finger. (He puts the wrong finger)nay, come, your middle-finger: so; now must I say a mystical form of powerful words, and then name those that we suspect
shall have her; and amongst them name you also; and at whose name the sieve turns, he shall have her.

sp.speaker: Geometres
sp.p: If it does not turn at mine, I shall die: pray make it turn at mine.

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: Nay, than it must go for nothing, for it must turn of its own accord. Be silent now. Dies mies, ieschet, bene doefet, Dowim●, Enitemaus. Who shall have astronomia? Shall poeta? (It stands still.)who shall have astronomia? Shall logicus?

sp.speaker: Geometres
sp.p: He's not in love with her, sir; pray do not you put in him too.

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: O vile! peace; now must I begin again. Diet mies, ieschet, bene doefet, dowima, Enitemaus. Who shall have astronomia? Shall poeta? (It stands still.)who shall have astronomia? Shall logicus? (It stands still.)who shall have astronomia? Shall Geographus? (It moves a little.)who shall have astronomia? Shall Geometres? (It turns round.)shall he obtain her by conjuration? (It stands still.)shall he obtain her by medicine? (It moves a little.)shall he obtain her by fascination? (It turns round.)

sp.speaker: Geometres
sp.p: Georaetres falls down on his knees, and embraces Magus his knees.Magus, what's mine is yours, goods, life, soul, and all: Venus, thy temple shall be a mile in length; thy image in't shall be greater than the colossus at Rhodes, it shall be all white marble: the temple at Milan shall look like pale-faced tallow to it; it shall have as many pillars, as there are hours in the year, and as many windows as there are minutes; and the spire shall be higher than Tenariffa, or the tower of Babylon by eight score measured furlongs at the least. Magus, I have enough, I have enough.

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: Nay but, sir, you must measure your joy; divers have died with overmuch rejoicing, and so may you; and then you'd both break your vow to the goddess, and lose your love besides.

sp.speaker: Geometres
sp.p: You say true.

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: Besides, you must use a means you see, fascination; which you shall use at the banquet, which (You know) we are invited unto.

sp.speaker: Geometres
sp.p:
Nay, let me alone for looking on her; I'll look
thorough her, and thorough her; and make her as perspective, as I am solid.

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: Besides, there was a little moving, you saw, at the name of Geographus: to signify he will be fair for her too. And again, there was a little moving at the word medicine, and therefore that must be used too: but for that take you no care.

sp.speaker: Geometres
sp.p: Well, you learned men put so many doubts — but I care not, I shall have her in the end: come, I've enough, now let's go.

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: Measure your joy, I say.

sp.speaker: Geometres
sp.p: Thou'rt mine, thou'rt mine, astronomia, I'm in heaven already; Geographus may go travail again, and poeta, in stead of baies, may go wear a willow-garland.

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: Come, let's in. Exeunt geometres and Magus.
Marry, and I be thus troubled with you when you woo me, and seek to please; what should I expect and we were married once?

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: Nay, dearest logicus, let not the excellency of your reason be so severe, but that it may admit a gracious apprehension of a smiling love; let not the exactness of your wisdom be so regulated, but that it may express a courteous acceptance of a lover's admiration; let not —

sp.speaker: Logic
sp.p: Nay, and you once fall to set speeches, I am gone; I perceive you are not for common talk; I wonder, now I think on't, in what predicament a woman's tongue is; let's see: yet, what if I make it a transcendent? and yet it can't be so, for 'tis neither unum, nor verum, nor honum: i'faith, an't be in any predicament, it shall be in quantitate continua, and that's opposite to discreta; or rather, since 'tis so irregular, and therefore can hardly be admitted into any order, I will count it that monster in nature, and contradiction of philosophy, infinitum in acta.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p:
Why lo, now yourself has made a set speech; and
thus whilst you reprehend, you offend: whilst you direct, you neglect: whilst you reform, you deform: whilst you —

sp.speaker: Logic
sp.p: Hey day! this is tick-tack: here's another shorter trick: well, I perceive there's no other course — which is your way?

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: Which is your way?

sp.speaker: Logic
sp.p: Do you speak first.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: Nay, do you speak first, you are the better man.

sp.speaker: Logic
sp.p: Why, mine lies this way.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: Why so does mine; we'll go together.

sp.speaker: Logic
sp.p: Ay, but I must go this way to do a little business first.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: Why so must I.

sp.speaker: Logic
sp.p: But I must walk here alone a little to think on't first.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: Why, and I must walk here alone a little first.

sp.speaker: Logic
sp.p: Why, then fare you well; I can think on my business by the way.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: Why, and I can very well think on my business by the way.

sp.speaker: Logic
sp.p: Why, you won't follow me? I am going to a feast.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: Why, and I am going to a feast.

sp.speaker: Logic
sp.p: I am going to Ethicus.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: Why, and I am going to Ethicus.

sp.speaker: Logic
sp.p: O you gods! which of you will come to deliver me? Well, if we must together, and if you will stick so close unto me; yet, good mistress tongue, do not cleave to the roof of my mouth.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: No, no; your lip is all that I desire.

div.head: Actus iii. Scaena iiii.
div.stage: Musica at one door: Geographus and Phantastes at another.

sp.p: Tara, ding de ding, ding de ding, lan, tan, dan, dido.

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: How now my nimble crotchet? who was the first fiddle-maker?

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Thats's a question, sir.

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: Why, for that reason I proposed it.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Why, for that reason you might have proposed many more.

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: Ay, but answer.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Ay, but I must know first; 'tis a great controversy.

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: What then was the first kind of instrument?

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Why, that's as hard.

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: Why, I can tell.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: An harp.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: I but you're deceived, I rather think 'twas a bagpipe.

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: A bagpipe? why prithee?

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Why? marry, first understand this reason, and then I'll show you: you know every art both draws it's imitation from nature, and labours to perfect it, which it does by finding comforts to preserve it: music then at the first was found out as an antidote against grief: and by this means, when men were grieved, they cried o, and there was one note: then hey-ho, there were two notes more. So, when they laughed, they observed three more by ha, ha, ho. These being first joined together, and afterwards variously intermixed, were the first harmony in voice; which being repeated unto grieved minds, were as it were a pretty deluding of their sorrows; and these by observation were afterwards reduced to instrument —

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: I conceit it, musica.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Thus, men perceiving that these notes were conceived in the belly, and afterwards, (As it were) formed in the passage of the throat, sowed leather in the form of a belly, or bag; and with a reed made a long neck unto it, and a windpipe; which when they blew full of wind, and perceived it gave no sound, they cut many holes in the reed to let it out, and then alternately stopping the holes, they found an admirable variety of harmony; and as the holes serve for distinction of notes in a wind-instrument, so do your frets on a stringed-instrument.

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p:
Indeed I think this a truth; for as the voice was before the instrument, so the wind-instrument before the
stringed. But then how came your trumpet up?

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Why, on this manner: when Triton came to help the gods in the wars of the giants, he wanted a weapon, and finding the shell of a fish, he did blow in't, which yielded a most hideous noise: the giants thinking it had been some terrible beast, fled away affrighted, and since by a perfecting imitation, men have altered both the matter, and the form of that instrument.

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: Nay, I do believe there is a great virtue in music.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: O sir, 'tis your only medicine of the mind.

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: Indeed I think so, and that's the reason, 'tis likely, why Apollo is the god both of music and physic: and now I remember it, in one place where we came, in our travails, there were no physicians, but all their sick folks were cured by music; where was it, Phantastes? I have quite forgotten.

sp.speaker: Phant.
sp.p: Why 'twas in Crete sir, where Jupiter was nursed, and the music was made with those kettledrums, which they sounded to drown the crying of Jupiter, when he was in his swath-bands: in reward of which love, he procured of Apollo, in the favour of the Cretians, that at the sound of those kettledrums all sick folks, whose time of death was not come, should without any languishing sickness immediately recover; and therefore the order is, when any one is sick, they carry him presently in a litter to the temple where these drums are kept; and if he does not straightways recover, they carry him home again, as a man that must die, and so provide for his funeral.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Where is this sir? in Crete?

sp.speaker: Phant.
sp.p: Yes, in Crete.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Ay, but I have heard, the Cretians are mighty liars.

sp.speaker: Phant.
sp.p: Upon the faith of a traveller, the honesty of a courtier, and the word of a gentleman, 'tis a most confirmed truth.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Indeed these three are much about one value.

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: Well, musica, I could talk with thee all day —

sp.speaker: Phant.
sp.p: Ay, and all night too.

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p:
But I cannot stay now; I'm afraid they stay for me
at the banquet. Is thy mistress there?

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: Yes, I think, by this time.

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: Well, farewell till anon: you'll meet us at supper? won't you?

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: Yes, yes; I'm going for music. Exit geogra.

sp.speaker: Phant.
sp.p: Come, my pretty pigeon, let's bill a little; is't possible, Phantastes and musica should meet, and part without a kiss? — now farewell. Exit Phantastes.

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: Ah: these courtiers are liquorish-lipped: but I must go fetch the music, to ra ding de ding, ding de ding, lan, tan dan dido. Exit musica.

div.head: Actus iii. Scaena v.
Ethicus, geometres, Logicus, poeta, Grammaticus, Magus, astronomia, arithmetica, rhetorica, astrologia, choler.

sp.p: Welcome, welcome, all of you; i'good faith, I'm e'en young again, to see such a jolly company of my friends together: but, passion of me! why, Oeconoma?

sp.speaker: Oecon.
sp.p: Ay, ay, presently, presently,She speaks from within.we're making all haste we can.

sp.speaker: Ethic.
sp.p: Ah, there's a good housewife, neither meat oth' table, nor cloth laid, nor any thing in a readiness. Good friends pardon us, we are somewhat unmannerly to make you stay thus; we'll talk till supper is served in; but where's Geographus? Enter Geographus and Phantastes.o here is; welcome, welcome.

sp.speaker: Geogr.
sp.p: Thanks,They all salute him, and he them mutually, especially the ladies.courteous Ethicus — save you gallants — fair ladies —

sp.speaker: Ethic.
sp.p: Phantastes, and choler,[enter musica]and thou musica, now thou art come, be a little forward to make a supply for our backwardness, and step in to my wife to help out supper quickly:(Exeunt phantast. Choler, and musica)why 'tis well, 'tis well, now 'tis as it should be, all friends, all friends: but where's Historia?

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: Historia? why, ask poeta.

sp.speaker: Poeta
sp.p: Me?

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: Ay, you; they say she's sick of love.

sp.speaker: Ethic.
sp.p: Poeta, where's your man Melancholico?

sp.speaker: Poeta
sp.p: Faith, when I was coming hither, he was in a dump, and therefore I thinking him not fit to come to a banquet, left him behind me; and indeed that's his fault, he will not commonly be merry in company.

sp.speaker: Ethic.
sp.p: Logicus, where's your man Phlegmatico?

sp.speaker: Logic
sp.p: Faith, as I was coming, my slaverer was at his tobacco, but, I think, I made him smoke for his labour, and so would not let him come, for he would nothing but have spawled in your room,Phantastes, choler, musica, bring in supper. and have turned your stomachs.

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: Well, remember this Phantastes.

sp.speaker: Phant.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: That you carry in the marchpane and not I, but I'll —

sp.speaker: Phant.
sp.p: What? ain't I the better man?

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: Would supper were done: I'd bum you.

sp.speaker: Geogr.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Phant.
sp.p: Why, sir, he's angry that I brought in the marchpane.

sp.speaker: Geogr.
sp.p: Phantastes, choler, musica, go out againcome, be mannerly.

sp.speaker: Gram.
sp.p: Why, sirrah, choler, will you still be quarrelling?

sp.speaker: Ethic.
sp.p: You should let him be my man a little; faith I should be as froward as he; we two should have a bickering once a day. (Choler to phantast. as they come in with more service.

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: I would supper were done once for your sake.

sp.speaker: Gram.
sp.p: Why, sirrah, are you still grumbling?

sp.speaker: Oecon.
sp.p: Come, friends, you are all welcome, we have made you stay here too-long for a little sorry cheer; come husband will you place the guests?

sp.speaker: Ethic.
sp.p: Sit down, you know your places; sit down(They all sit down)wife, bid them welcome.

sp.speaker: Oecon.
sp.p: You are all heartily welcome, heartily welcome.

sp.speaker: Ethic.
sp.p: Why, musica, where are the musicians?

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: Here, sir, here.

sp.speaker: Ethic.
sp.p: Come on, play, feed you our ears, whilst we seed our bellies. The music plays; Geographus drinks to astronomia; she to Geometria; he to arithmetica she to Astrologia; she drinks to astronomia, then ●●ally casts in a powder: which being done, Phantastes sings.

lg.l: If you fell not at odds,
But when pride does once tickle,
And bring us in tune again.

Where music and love do meet!
To make his pipe sound more sweet:

sp.speaker: Ethic.
sp.p: Here, logicus, you shall drink to poeta,

sp.speaker: Logic
sp.p: I accept your proposition, sir; poeta, to set a conclusion to our former dissensions, and to make a plain demonstration of reconcilement, I drink to you. He drinks.

sp.speaker: Poeta
sp.p: With the most ingenuous freedom of a poet, I accept it: Grammaticus, that our contention ending in love, may make a tragic-comedy, I drink to you. He drinks.

sp.speaker: Gram.
sp.p: I protest to you, sir, I do put all former wrongs in the preterpluperfect tense, and am glad of this happy conjunction, and that we are all of us in such a merry mood: but by the way, my masters, these noune-adiectiues of the feminine gender, sit all this while undrunk to: astronomia. He offers to drink to astronomia. —

sp.speaker: Astron.
sp.p: Intruth, Grammaticus, I am not in case to pledge you: I pledged Astrologia even now, and I am not since half well.

sp.speaker: Gram.
sp.p: Arithmetica —

sp.speaker: Arith.
sp.p: If you count again, you shall find that I drunk last.
Rhetorica — here's to moisten your eloquent tongue.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p: An eloquent tongue is never dry, Astrologia will pledge you for me.

sp.speaker: Gram.
sp.p: Astrologia —

sp.speaker: Astrologia
sp.p: In troth I have been drinking my belly full of nectar; but just now, my thoughts were upon the present conjunction of Mars and Venus.

sp.speaker: Poeta
sp.p: Why how now, Grammaticus! who do you drink to? faith thou art now a noun substantive indeed, for thou standst alone by thyself, without being joined to any of these adjectives.

sp.speaker: Gram.
sp.p: Nay, do not you jest.

sp.speaker: Poeta
sp.p: What? dost thou make a jester of me?

sp.speaker: Magician
sp.p: Nay, I conjure you both; by our present meeting, that you go not out of the circle of harmless mirth.

sp.speaker: Poeta
sp.p: methinks I see a direct line pass from the eye of Geometres to Astronomia's.

sp.speaker: Magician
sp.p: Nay, will you, poeta? you make astronomia blush.

sp.speaker: Poeta
sp.p: Some aqua vitae, I say, for Geometres.

sp.speaker: Magician
sp.p: Why, poeta?

sp.speaker: Poeta

sp.speaker: Astronomia
sp.p: I'm e'en stifled, I do not use to be in such a close room, I love the open air.

sp.speaker: Oecon.
sp.p: Alas! Astronomia's extreme ill. Exeunt astronomia and Oeconoma.

sp.speaker: Ethic.
sp.p: Friends, you are all heartily welcome, rest you here I pray, and we'll in with her. Exit ethicus.

sp.speaker: Magician
sp.p: Astrologia, follow her, and see you be never from her all the while she's sick.

sp.speaker: Astrologia
sp.p: I saw this disastrous chance in the stars, for as Mars and Venus were sporting, they were beheld by the rest of the envious gods. Exit.

sp.speaker: Rhet.
sp.p:
I'll in too, to sit and talk with her, whiles she's
sick. Exit rhetorica.

sp.speaker: Arith.
sp.p: I'll in too, that I may —

sp.speaker: Geogr.
sp.p: Be made sit down again.

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: Alas, my mistress!

sp.speaker: Geogr.
sp.p: She did not look well.

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: Astronomia sick? than all the heaven's awry, and my music's quite out of tune. Exit musica.

sp.speaker: Geogr.
sp.p: 'Twas, I fear me, a fit of an ague.

sp.speaker: Magician
sp.p: Astronomia in a fit of an ague? I never understood the motus trepidationis of the heaven before.

sp.speaker: Geogr.
sp.p: Musicians, depart the room. The musicians go out.

sp.speaker: Poeta
sp.p: By Jove I came to be merry, and I will be merry. Here's an health to astronomia. He drinks.

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: Here's a health to astronomia. He drinks.

sp.speaker: Geometres
sp.p: Here's a health to astronomia. He drinks.

sp.speaker: Poeta
sp.p: Sir, you wrong us all, not to take off your full measure.

sp.speaker: Geometres
sp.p: O, sir, they that drink with measure, drink without measure.

sp.speaker: Arith.
sp.p: Ay, indeed, for they that number their cups, commonly multiply their cups.

sp.speaker: Poeta
sp.p: He loves not astronomia, that does not pledge her a whole one.

sp.speaker: Geometres
sp.p: Well, because 'tis to her, I'll do't,He drinks.

sp.speaker: Logic
sp.p: I can't drink.

sp.speaker: Gram.
sp.p: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Magician
sp.p: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Arith.
sp.p: You won't, I know, require it of me.

sp.speaker: Poeta
sp.p: Well, and you won't, here's to you that will: a second health to astronomia. He drinks.

sp.speaker: Geogr.
sp.p: A second health to astronomia. He drinks.

sp.speaker: Geometres
sp.p: A second health to astronomia. He drinks.

sp.speaker: Phant.
sp.p: By Jove I must be merry, and I will be merry; can you sing?

sp.speaker: Geogr.
sp.p: Begin, we'll follow.

sp.p: Faith, I can drink no more, poeta.

sp.speaker: Geometres
sp.p: Nor I.

sp.p: How? not pledge me? Choler, fill the bowl again; by Jove, not pledge me? pledge me, pledge me, Geographus: for by Jove —

sp.p: What?

sp.p: I will drink with thee, and I will sing with thee, and I will fight with thee.

sp.speaker: Magician
sp.p: Nay, pray let's have no fighting.

sp.speaker: Poeta
sp.p: By Jove. I will drink with thee, I will sing with thee, and I will fight with thee.

sp.p: By Jove you're almost foxed.

sp.speaker: Poeta
sp.p: By Jove(He drinks)you lousy-shirted rogue, you sit above me? did not you beg entertainment of me tother day?

sp.speaker: Geogr.
sp.p: Sleep, sleep, poeta. Exit Geographus.

sp.speaker: Phant.
sp.p: A rope of a drunken fool; I've lost my supper by this: I must follow my master. Exit Phant.

sp.speaker: Poeta
sp.p: Ten-toes, I know you're a good footman; come, Geometres, I hope you'll sit squarely to it still.

sp.speaker: Geometres
sp.p: Nay, if I cannot rule others, I will rule myself. Exit geometres.

sp.speaker: Arith.
sp.p: And if Geometres depart, arithmetica will be none of the number. Exit Arith.

sp.speaker: Poeta
sp.p: Farewell, hostess; we shall be sure to have no reckoning now Arithmetica's gone: and yet I'll pay you somewhat, clinch-fist. (He beats logicus, and overturns the table; then falls on grammaticus, and choler.)hay tables! Hay!

sp.speaker: Logic
sp.p:
Well, you drunken rogue, I'll have an opposition
for you before Polites, that you shall not be able to answer to. Exit logicus.

sp.speaker: Poeta
sp.p: Farewell blockhead: now pedagogue, pedagogue: I must say my part to you too.

sp.speaker: Gram.
sp.p: Ay, but, I can't stay to hear you, now.

sp.speaker: Poeta
sp.p: Choler, will not you fight for your master, valiantly?

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: No, I thank you, sir, your moisture does allay my heat. Exit choler.

sp.speaker: Poeta
sp.p: Are you all gone? then, apparent rari nantes in gurgite vasto. I am King, I am King: by Tantalus I am as dry as an horse. He falls down and sleeps. Magus charms him.o, some drink, some drink.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.

sp.speaker: Phys.
sp.p: What will he do?

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: By the — by the —

sp.speaker: Magician
sp.p: He's about to swear sure by somewhat.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: By the great — by the great —

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: He will swear by the great.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: By the great — by the great —

sp.speaker: Phys.
sp.p: 'Tis so great 'twon't come out.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: By the great hogshead at Heidelberg, logicus is a blockhead.

sp.speaker: Phys.
sp.p: Well said i'faith, I perceive there is some remembrance of ones friends in wine.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: Corinna, will you kiss? will you kiss cockle-kiss? close, close, you whore.

sp.speaker: Magician
sp.p: O, here's a brave dreamer!

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: I will make this verse like a nuthook-like a nut-hooke-and then pull down — pull down the moon with it. He begins to rise.

sp.speaker: Phys.
sp.p: Sure, Magus, you han't charmed him well.

sp.speaker: Magician
sp.p: Let me alone; I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: Come kiss, my pigeon, come kiss, my pretty Corinna, nibble a little, my love; nibble again, and again.

sp.speaker: Magician
sp.p: Hay day! he's at's hexameter and pentameter verses in our tongue: 'faith I think in some such humour this kind of verses was first made amongst us.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: My purse is richer than th' mines rich India brings forth.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: You shall not need to make a short verse to that sir: we'll be very short with you. He is about to pick his pocket.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: Take off your whole one, or take a souse of the chops. Poeta strikes Cheiromantes

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: Beshrew his drunken fingers; Magus you ha' not charmed him well.

sp.speaker: Magician
sp.p:
Altè dormi, pax, prax, max; aliè dormi, galbos, galbat:
Galdes, galdat: pax, prax, max, alte dormi. Poeta falls down again.

sp.speaker: Phys.
sp.p: See what's in his pocket. Cheiromantes takes out a purse and looks in it.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: A murrain on't, here's nothing but a purse with a paper in't.

sp.speaker: Magician
sp.p: Let's see it, why, what's here? Verses! He takes the paper and reads it.
Translated by me upon occasion of Ethicus his inviting me to supper.

quote.l: The fruitful earth does drink the rain;
Trees drinks the fruitful earth again.
The sea does drink the liquid air;
By the sun's beams the sea-waves are
Drunk up; which is no sooner done,
But straight the moon drinks up the sun.
Why then, companions, do you think
I may not with like freedom drink?

sp.p: This had been lost, if I had not given the rogue his Anacreon again. Is this the rich purse? Come, i'faith we'll e'en serve for a voider, and carry him away, whiles he is drunk, rid the room of him.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Room for a poet, room for a poet, room for a poet. Exeunt omnes, carrying away poeta on their shoulders.
And have you been in Italy too?

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: In the most parts of the world, sir.

sp.speaker: Polites.
sp.p: You have disposed your observations by heads! have you not?

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: They are yet sir but a miscellany, but I am now in reducing of them.

sp.speaker: Polites.
sp.p: And what may the sum of them be?

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: Sir, they are principally drawn from the people, and country: discoursing upon the policy, and natural disposition of the first; as on the situation, and fertility of the second.

sp.speaker: Polites.
sp.p: Hum, the method is sufficiently approvable: but I like that very well that you place policy first; and would wish you to prosecute that fully, with the most subtle examinations of your purest judgement: 'twill be worth your travail: and 'tis a main fault of your common geographers, that nowadays do rather garnish the margin of a map, then materially describe it; and only draw a company of lines through it; as if they had rid over the country to take notice only of the highways; which yet a carrier's horse knows better than they; neglecting in the mean time more solid observations; whilst their fancies (I will not say judgements) are weakly satisfied with these fruitless superficialities; not unlike your sedentary students, who for the attaining of a little glory with some few less judicious of their own sect, stirred up with a contemplative ambition, earnestly prosecute those studies, which themselves shall never reduce unto practice, in the actions of their life.

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: Sir, the observation of government was my first and principal intendment, especially in some secrets of state, as yet (To my knowledge) not observed, at least not revealed by any.

sp.speaker: Polites.
sp.p: As what?

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: I will show unto you.

sp.speaker: Polites.
sp.p: But how could you come unto the knowledge of them?

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: You shall understand that too. The secret is concerning the happy detection of such, as from enemy-states, are usually sent to the subversion of a land; my means of attaining to the knowledge of this mystery, was my acquaintance with a gentleman in Italy, who having been one of the most practised intelligencers in Europe, upon the death of his lord, who employed him, fell into great wants; when, out of the fullness of a grieved mind, and the rather to excite in me a compassion of his griefs, unfolded unto me the whole secret.

sp.speaker: Polites.
sp.p: Proceed.

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p:
The Italian lord, that employed this gentleman, furnished him always with money, that he might cast himself
into what shape he would, then sent him to the enemy's land, where living, (Either concealing his own country, or professing a dislike of it) and insinuating himself into the acquaintance of men next to the best, would, commonly by entertaining their humours, and giving occasion of such discourse at any meeting, with much art and ease, allure every man, to discover (Even for glory, to show who could show most) all intended and secret employments into foreign lands; by this means he would learn the whole design, agent, time, and whatsoever other necessary circumstance; then the person to be employed, being commonly of estate not beyond himself, he would upon some sought (Though but slight) occasion, grow so far acquainted with him, as to entreat the courtesy of nations of him, to carry a letter from him to that country; which being with all courtesy granted, he would, against the time of his departure, provide a letter fairly written, containing nothing but some compliment, or lighter business to his friend —

sp.speaker: Polites.
sp.p: Who? to his lord?

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: No, sir, but to another agent, whom his lord employed at home, as this gentleman abroad.

sp.speaker: Polites.
sp.p: Proceed then.

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: Withal giving his friend in charge, upon their love, to give all courteous entertainment to the bearer thereof; as, to provide him a fit lodging, with all other compliments of friendship: then reading this letter to the gentleman, to free him from all suspicion of false dealing, would seal it in his presence, and deliver it to him —

sp.speaker: Polites.
sp.p: What device was there in this?

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: This letter, sir, being written by the art of steganography, contained the whole intendment of this imployd messenger. That art (As Trithemius has at large discovered, or rather taught it) proceeds upon many devices, as the putting together every first letter of a word, or every last, or every second, according to the compact before laid between these two friends. Upon the receipt of which, proceeded first a most courteous entertaining, and then upon the maturity of his intendments, an artificial detection of all his designs.

sp.speaker: Polites.
sp.p: All this bears a just probability of truth. Well, Geographus, we shall take a further notice of your wants and worth; and since you have ingeniously discovered both your free education, present state, and unavoidable affection to astronomia, and, as you say, hers mutually to you, I shall, I trust, effectually, in your behalf, remove the unwillingness of her mother Physica. But withal, I hold it a course, not altogether without policy, to inquire of astronomia, the dislikes, for which she does except against you, and therein by a praevenient discretion, exactly to manifest a reformation; for this time the expectation of some business admits not a further continuance of our discourse.

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: I shall rest, sir, at the bounty of your virtue.

sp.speaker: Polites.
sp.p: A gentleman of parts worth the taking notice of; well, such wits must be nourished: 'tis the saying of my Tacitus: ingenia, studique oppresseris faciliùs quàm revocaveris; and I remember he there shows an analogy between men's wits and their bodies: they are (Saith he) both of them long a making, but soon marred. And indeed, young wits that are worth the nourishing, when they see themselves neglected, are too-too prone to fall to desperate resolutions, arguing thus with themselves, that if virtue and learning cannot advance them; by a reason from the contrary, neither vice nor ignorance can debase them; thus from bad premises drawing a worse conclusion, they overthrow in a moment the workmanship of many years. But my kinswoman Historia said she would be here by this. O, here she comes.
Now cousin, what? always sad? always sad?

sp.speaker: Histo.
sp.p: Do you admire at my sadness, when you know, nay when you are the cause of it?

sp.speaker: Polites.
sp.p: I? Cousin? how? how?

sp.speaker: Histo.
sp.p:
Your continual declamations, sir, against my most
loved poeta, a man whose praises admit no hyperbole; no, they transcend all; and whose worth we may admire rather than express.

sp.speaker: Polites.
sp.p: Why cousin? my declamations ha' been only against his faults, not his person, and so far —

sp.speaker: Histo.
sp.p: Nay, for your state-distinctions you may reserve them to yourself, you can love and hate the same man at the same time by a distinction; I do but plainly relate the truth unto you, and I think there is hardly any man could more violently have inveighed against him then yourself; excepting old froward Ethicus; his age indeed must always be correcting somebody .

sp.speaker: Polites.
sp.p: Why, but why should you regard him, when it seems he little regards you?

sp.speaker: Histo.
sp.p: Marry, and little reason he hath, when he sees the best of my friends, yourself, and Ethicus to neglect him. But otherwise I'm sure he did love me once: there have been of the historias that have been well beloved by poets, and those the most renowned in all ages: as by admired Homer, the greatest glory and shame of Greece, the one for his worth, the other for his wants: then by divine Maro, that beautiful wonder of nature; and especially by one Lucan, a worthy gentleman of Rome, besides many more; that if you would vouchsafe but to grace him, his laurel would be the crown of your glory.

sp.speaker: Polites.
sp.p: I but he bears love to astronomia.

sp.speaker: Hist.
sp.p:
I understand so much: but I think that rather the exiliency of some passion, than any consistency of a settled desire. I have indeed heard also of some of the Astronomias that have been beloved by poets; as by Manilius, Pontanus, and some other, who have written whole books in the praise of their beauties; but it seems their beauties had such small divinity in them, that they could not raise, to any height of poetic rapture, the wits of their admirers. And there was also one Lucretius, a Roman gentleman, in former times that fell in love with Physica, she from whom Physica the mother of astronomia derives now both her name and lineage, which gentleman, in the passion of his love, writ books in the praise
of her beauty; but what wrinkle-faced verses they are, let the present age judge; and if her beauty was like his lines, sure she was passed her threescore, when he fell in love with her; but alas, there was never any of that family that ever came near the historias for beauty.

sp.speaker: Polites.
sp.p: Well, cousin, then what is the employment wherewith you will task me?

sp.speaker: Hist.
sp.p: Why, if you mean to have me alive long, change your dislike of poeta into love, and reform him if you will, but not hate him; admonish him, entreat him, woo him, and in a word, win him unto me; and those hymns of your praises, and relations of your glory shall be put in the mouth of posterity; that sooner shall the commonwealth die, than your fame.

sp.speaker: Polites.
sp.p: Well, cousin, you have now enough admonished me, entreated me, wooed me, and in a word won me: refer the finding out of means, and the accomplishing of your desire to the privacy of my meditations.

sp.speaker: Histor.
sp.p: Reverend Polites, pardon the unmannerliness of my disordered passions; love resisted grows rude and furious: but I will not instruct your wisdom; only remember my life lies in your hands.

sp.speaker: Polites.
sp.p: And that shall not perish if I can save it. There are many accusations in against this poeta, and some of them I perceive will be prosecuted; he has bad, and good parts; he has a wild head, yet may be reformed, and then there's a man saved: a good purchase; nay, Historia is saved, that's a double. Well, then since I must love him, I will save him: if he prove good, I win two; if bad, 'twill be but the loss of one, of Historia; who already professes, that, without him, she shall be lost.

div.head: Actus iv. Scaena iii.
Astronomia, astrologia, arithmetica, poeta, Medicus, musica.

sp.p: O, I'm so hot, I could drink a whole river of water.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p:
Nay, if you talk of drinking, I could drink my
self half a dozen Helicons off at a draught: musica, fetch a flagon of wine.

sp.speaker: Astronomia
sp.p: Nay, let it be pure water.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Have a care what you do: 'tis as much as your life's worth.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: By Jove we will have our liquor about us. Go wench, why, sir, should not she drink?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Why, to drink in the heat of an ague is present death; and I remember Galen in his book de consuetudine, relates a story of Arius a peripatetic, who died suddenly, being forced to drink a full draught of cold water in the heat of his fever; though according to the prescriptions of his physicians: yet, I confess, in him there was another adjoined cause, which Galen in the same place makes mention of, to wit, his stomach being always very cold, he resolved on a perpetual abstinence from all cold nourishments, so that this adventitious cold of the water he drank, wrought not only against his disease, but also against his constitution.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: O that was it, that was it; then fill out the liquor.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: You poets would make mad physicians; or at the best but desperate Paracelsians; but astronomia, you stir too much; and so the heat of your disease increases to an inflammation: you must rest more, you must rest more.

sp.speaker: Astronomia
sp.p: Nay, I shall never live, if I leave moving.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Ay, but not so fast; you walk as fast as you do when you are in health.

sp.speaker: Astrologia
sp.p: Indeed, methinks , she keeps always the same pace.

sp.speaker: Arith.
sp.p: Ay, but if you mark it, 'tis not a direct progression, but a kind of giddy turning round, which proceeds from a lightness of the head, caused by her disease.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: I dislike your diet; for in the very hottest of summer, when the sun is in cancer, you eat the hottest meat, feeding altogether upon crab; which two concurrent heats of the meat and of the weather, are able to cast any man into the inflammation of a fever.

sp.speaker: Astronomia
sp.p: Indeed, I confess that; and 'tis at that season, my only diet.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Ay, but 'tis bad; and again 'tis very good to feed upon variety of meat.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: Say you so! marry, I think, you'll prove a paradoxical Paracelsian yourself; if you hold such tenants: for you know, sir, 'tis the most received opinion of physicians, that variety of meats disturbs concoction.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Sir, I hold that opinion rather to argue the author's superstition, than judgement: for our nature delighteth in variety, and those meats which the stomach doth with pleasure desire, it doth most embracingly attract, and concoct most faithfully, besides the substance of our bodies consisting of a various nature, as moisture, air, and the like, one of these parts may be more spent then another, by labour, or other means; so that a man had need, for the undoubted supply of all these parts, receive a great variety of nourishments, that there may be a reparation for whatsoever the body does evacuate.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: I understand sir.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Besides, astronomia, going abroad you never take care in what air you walk.

sp.speaker: Astronomia
sp.p: Indeed, I confess, I am too neglective of that.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: O, that's a chief matter to be provided for; for the very same air sometimes is hurtful for one part of the body, and good for another.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: How? is that possible?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Sir, 'tis a truth observed by Guido cauliacensis; and in particular of the air of Paris; where, if the same man have a wound in his head, and another in his thigh; it hurts the one and heals the other.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: That's pretty i'faith: the reason, the reason, master physician.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p:
'Tis thus, sir, the air there is cold and moist, and therefore most hurtful for the head; and again, the same air by an obscuration of the spirits, a degravation of the blood, and a condensation of the humours, whereby they are made less quick to flow down, does therefore make the wounds of the thighs more curable, whiles the course of the humours is intercepted, whose defluence or flowing down
would hinder the cure of the wound.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: You physicians, I perceive, sometimes have some of Apollo in you.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Pray, Medicus, tell me one thing; you're a physician; I have heard Geographus relate of a place in his travels, where the people are healed by music: is that possible?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: O yes: I'll confirm it by mine own experience: I knew a young gentle man that married a young gentlewoman; who being extraordinarily fair, and he as melancholy, grew into a great jealousy, that she had made him a cuckold, upon which conceit, at the first but light, the strength of his melancholy and jealousy working together; he fell into a strong persuasion that he had horns: the best physicians were sent for, used all medicines and inventions to cure him, nothing prevailed, whereupon they left him, entreating his wife to be patient, and expect his recovery in time. Away they went, and none but a little boy was left in the room to tend the gentleman, when upon a sudden there comes me by, a bag-pipe-player, at the sound of whose pipe the gentleman suddenly arose, leaps about the chamber, beats his head against the wall, so long, till at last he had broke his face in divers places that the blood gushed out; upon the effusion of which melancholy blood, that had corrupted his brain and fantasy, the gentleman's horns were beaten off against the wall, and the gentlewoman became as honest a woman after that time, as any in Europe.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: In good faith, you physicians are the only fellows in the world to tell tales by gentlewomen's bedsides, whiles they are sick.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Ay, this cure was by the effusion of blood, but they whom Geographus told of, were healed without any such means.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p:
I'll satisfy you in that by another particularity of experience: I knew another gentleman, who being very sick of a contagious disease, and finding no remedy by medicine, the physicians caused musicians to be brought into the room, and play; at the hearing of which music, he suddenly leaps and continued dancing so long, till the laborious
exagitation of his whole body, had by sweat and breathing dissipated the contagion.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: I wonder you physicians do not turn travelers, you'd have an advantage beyond them all, by making good your relations, by giving a reason for them.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: O by no means, sir; for if we should travail into foreign lands, our skill would there fail us; by reason of the difference of the country, and our ignorance of their constitutions and diet.

sp.speaker: Astronomia
sp.p: Musica, some drink; methinks , I have not one jot of moisture in me.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Musica, fetch none, she shall drink no more.

sp.speaker: Astronomia
sp.p: I must drink, the world was not in such a combustion at Phaeton's driving the chariot of the sun, as I am in now.

sp.speaker: Astrologia
sp.p: Come, come, Medicus, the strictness of your prescriptions must be dispensed with, a little.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Will you spoil her, Astrologia?

sp.speaker: Astrologia
sp.p: I'll warrant you, she'll never die of this disease, I have calculated her nativity, to know so much beyond your art: the sixth house of her horoscope, wherein all her diseases are prefiguratively registered, promises a better issue of her sickness then so: besides, she shall have an happy womb, for I find in her horoscope, Venus in her exaltation, to wit, in pisces, and Jupiter in the fifth house, the radiation of Venus falling on the first house, and of Jupiter on the eleventh, Luna being in the seventh, illustrating the fifth house with a sextile radiation; she shall have a beautiful daughter, her name shall be optica: there shall appear at her birth four suns, and as many rainbows, and the air over-against these rainbows, shall seem to be full of looking-glasses, and in the middle of each rainbow shall appear a peacock's tail, which being reflected from the looking-glasses, shall project an infinity of colours in the air.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Astronomia, you go too much, you'll never leave your walking, and if Copernicus were alive again, i'faith he'd make you stand still.

sp.speaker: Astronomia
sp.p: Some drink. She drinks and falls.

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: Help, astronomia falls.

sp.speaker: Poeta.
sp.p: Marry, heavens forbid.

sp.speaker: Medic.
sp.p: Ay, here's your drink.

sp.speaker: Arith.
sp.p: Ah, astrologia, you made no reckoning of this sickness, I shall scarce e'er trust you again, as long as I know you: come, let's have her in, let's have her in. Exeunt omnes.

Now my sweet devils, I am even sick with expecting when Medicus will come and visit me: I fear, his physic cannot work upon poeta: that rogues verses, I think, are a countercharm against all our conjurations: a rope on his six-footed lousy hexameters: sure, the slave's skin is enchanted; the quilting of Aiax shield was but a thin chevril to it.

sp.speaker: Physiog.
sp.p: Why, but do you think 'tis impenetrable?

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: O, far tougher than a tanner's: I have heard of a poet, that having been buried a matter of two or three hundred years, has been taken up again whole, without the least perishing of his skin, as fair as any Vellome.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: Nay, by this hand, I hold them to be everlasting villains.

sp.speaker: Physiog.
sp.p: And I know by his looks, if he once settle his affection upon a wench, he'll pursue her more swiftly than ever Apollo did Daphne; for he'll overtake her before her metamorphosis.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: Ay, and I know the rascal to have a soft and moist hand, by which I also infallibly know he loves: for take a poet without his wine and his wench; and if he make not dry, pitiful dry verses, I'll forswear fortune-telling as long as I live.

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: But, I hope, that wench shall not be astronomia.

sp.speaker: Physiog.
sp.p: Ne'er fear that: I have seriously observed (Taking an opportunity the other day to look on her) the whole composure of her face; and first for her beauty, I must confess it absolute; for there are the two causes of all beauty; a most exquisite symmetry, or correspondent commensuration of the parts; and an exact mixture of colours, which adds unto the proportion an incomprehensible pulchritude: since which time, I have taken a like view of Geographus and Geometres; now for their heights, Geographus is somewhat lower than she; but Geometres is of her pitch just; for the lines of proportion in their faces, I must confess, I can hardly judge which is most like her, well, I hope yet 'twill be Geometres, or if Geographus do win her, 'twill be by his comely deportment: i'faith I wish him well, but we must work for them that feel us in the fist.

sp.speaker: Magus.
sp.p: Well, ravens, croak here, and whosoever comes by, make a prey of him; in the mean time I'll to Astrologia, for I know not what's the reason on't, but my spirits cannot inform me of any thing she does, so that I must of necessity to Astrologia, to know how things proceed: but there's one Galilaus an exquisite mathematician, an Italian: whom I came very lately acquainted with, by admirable luck; and he has promised to help me to a glass, by which I shall see all things as perfectly represented in Astronomia's house, as if I were there: till which time I must take the pains to have it by relation; but to your charge, to your charge; croak ravens, croak.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: Here comes somebody , Physiognomus; set a good face on't and affront him; and I'll set my fingers a work, presently.

sp.speaker: Physiog.
sp.p: Hold thy hands there, 'tis Sanguis, he's of our side, stay a little.

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p:
Well, I shrewdly suspect my master for this physic:
but mum, I am o'erheard, I fear.

sp.speaker: Physiog.
sp.p: How now, Sanguis? why dost thou blush so?

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: Do I blush?

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: I'm sure thou lookest as red as fire; I think all the blood in thy body is in thy face.

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: Well, well, all your words will not make me a jot redder than I am: but, if you talk of blushing, I think you have more need to blush, if you knew the report that goes of you.

sp.speaker: Physiog.
sp.p: Of us?

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: Ay, of you; but especially of Cheiromantes.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: Of me? what?

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: Nothing, but that you are a cutpurse.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: I defy mine accusers, and I call honesty itself to witness, that I get my living by my finger's ends.

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: Come, come, leave these protestations: a bad cause is better defended by silence, than argument.

sp.speaker: Physiog.
sp.p: Faith 'tis true; let us be friends: and since thy master Medicus has taught thee to kill, we'll teach thee to steal: but honestly, Sanguis, honestly.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: We three will set upon the next man we meet.

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: I would 'twere choler that broke my head tother day: of that condition, I'd stay; but my master has sent me to Magus. I must begone.

sp.speaker: Physiog.
sp.p: Nay, stay a little longer now, Sanguis: who comes yonder? do you know his face?

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: Well, you woe will help me?

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: My hand shall be always ready to help my friend.

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: Choler gives sanguis a box on the ear, and they fall to cuffs.choler, I'm Sanguis, and here's my head.

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: Sanguis, I'm choler and here's my hand.

sp.speaker: Melan.
sp.p: How? three against one? Hercules himself could not fight with such disadvantage: there's no ingenuity in this; I'll take his part for pity-sake at adventure, be it right or wrong. He helps choler

sp.speaker: Physiog.
sp.p: O my nose, my nose —

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: I'll make you too Sanguis cry your bloody nose before I ha' done.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: O my hand! my hand! O you rogue, you bow it quite double almost.
sp.stage: Enter musica with a pack and a bottle of drink.

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: Why men, beasts, furies, what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Melan.
sp.p: Choler, choler, draw thy knife, and flit Physiognomus his nose.

sp.speaker: Physiog.
sp.p: Ah you dull rogue, do you kick?
sp.stage: Enter Phlegmatico with a pipe of tobacco.

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: O, Phlegmatico! thou'rt welcome; but prithee throw away thy pipe; unless 'twere one could make them dance after it, and so cool their fury.

sp.speaker: Phleg.
sp.p: Why, ho!

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: Orpheus, they say, by music held beasts by the ears; let musica then hold the beastly furies of you, that are now by the ears.

sp.speaker: Phleg.
sp.p: Why, ho! They leave fighting.

sp.speaker: Melan.
sp.p: He has picked my pocket. Sirrah, Cheiromantes, you rogue, where's my handkercher?

sp.speaker: Phleg.
sp.p: Nay, give him his handkercher, I saw you take it: there, there is thy handkercher, Melancholico: why I thought thou hadst been no fighter.

sp.speaker: Melan.
sp.p: I'faith, ingenuity made me fight, when I saw three upon one.

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: Come, come, for shame, be friends; you shall all be friends before you part.

sp.speaker: Melan.
sp.p: Nay, I'm angry with nobody : I did but fight, to make them leave fighting.

sp.speaker: Physiog.
sp.p: Nor we; for the quarrel was not ours.

sp.speaker: Cheir.
sp.p: Nor we; for the quarrel was not ours.

sp.speaker: Phleg.
sp.p: I thought 'twas choler, and Sanguis, they still are provoking one another: what hast thou in thy bottle, musica? Nepenthe to reconcile the gods?

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: I'faith here's drink to reconcile these furies, if they will?

sp.speaker: Phleg.
sp.p: Come, musica, do you begin, and we'll all dance after thy pipe.

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p:
You have spoke truer than you think, for there is a piper coming after me, and somebody else; they'll be here
anon: well, here's to you all then. She drinks. He drinks.

sp.speaker: Melan.
sp.p: Phlegmatico, here's to thee.

sp.speaker: Phleg.
sp.p: Sanguis, here's to thee.

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: Choler, here's to thee.

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: Cheiromantes, have at you.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: Work. (Choler drinks) Physiognomus, will you taste this liquor?

sp.speaker: Physiog.
sp.p: Play off: (Cheiromantes drinks) well then, I am last, I'll drink to you all; I'll leave ne'er a jot: (He drinks) there, musica, there's thy bottle.

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: Sanguis and choler shake hands; are you friends?

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: Cheiromantes, they say, you can tell fortunes; is it true?

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: Try me.

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: Let's know all our fortunes then.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: Come on, let me see your hand, sweet musica: you shall be beloved of two, a courtier and a scholar; you shall love the courtier more; but the scholar shall have you; and it shall so come to pass, that the courtier shall afterwards be your servant: your husband shall be exceeding melancholy: you shall have three sons; the first shall be called by his father's name (But I know not what that shall be) and he shall be extreme discontent and solitary; and if he prevent a consumption, he may live till forty; for longer he cannot, being of a cold and dry constitution: the second shall be called Timido, and he'll be indanger of being bit with a mad dog; which if he scape, he may live till fifty: the third shall be called jucundo; the other two took after their father; but he'll take after his mother; he will be exceedingly given to good cheer, music, and women: he will be in danger of a surfeit; and of fire; and if he scape these two, especially burning, he may live to be an old man.

sp.speaker: Phleg.
sp.p: Tell me mine next.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: You, Phlegmatico; 'twill be long ere you can get you a wife; yet you'll have one, and one daughter; the child will die very young, of the black jaundice, and your wife of the dropsy.

sp.speaker: Phleg.
sp.p: Sirrah, I saw you steal before, and now I hear you lie, you rogue.

sp.speaker: Melan.
sp.p: Tell me mine next.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: I'll tell you yours in your ear. He whispers in Melancholico's ear.

sp.speaker: Melan.
sp.p: Thanks, dear Cheiromantes.

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: Nay, and fortunes be so good that are told in ones ear; I'll have mine told in my care too.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: Thus 'tis then. He whispers in his ear.

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: Pish, this is no such fine fortune.

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: Tell me mine openly.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: Why, this 'tis: you, choler, shall be somewhat happy in your wife: her name shall be poenitentia; you shall have two children; and one shall take only after you, his name shall be Furioso. He shall die in his young age, in an alehouse, of a stab in at the mouth, which shall pass thorough his tongue, and brains. The other child shall be a daughter; she shall take after her mother; her name shall be lacryma, a modest sober girl, and one that shall be well beloved by wise men.

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: Well, this is a pretty mixed fortune; now, what's thine own fortune and thy fellows?

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: O, stark naught, stark naught; I'll conceal them.

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: Then fare you well; I can stay no longer.

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: I'faith you shan't go yet; what have you in your pack?

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: What's that to you?

sp.speaker: Melan.
sp.p: Prethee, musica, tell me, what thou hast in thy pack?

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: Why, because you speak kindly now, and entreat me, I'll show you.

sp.speaker: Melan.
sp.p: Hay, brave! what's here?

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: Morris-bells?

sp.speaker: Phleg.
sp.p: And waistcoats, and napkins?

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: Why, how cam'st thou by them?

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p:
Why, thus: my mistress had been ill a good while, and because I tended her very carefully; she gave me leave to recreate myself today; and i'faith I light on merry company, where they used these jinglers: and when they had
done, they prayed me to carry them home with this bottle of drink.

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: Faith, and there were enough, we'd dance.

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: Enough? now I think on't, there's just enough, there's six pair.

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: Faith we'll to it then, but what wouldst thou do, musica?

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: Why, I'll play the maid Marian.

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: A match, a match: dress, dress, we'll have brave jingling. 〈…〉.

sp.speaker: Melan.
sp.p: I can't dance.

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: Nay, prithee be not sullen, good Melancholico.

sp.speaker: Melan.
sp.p: If I do, I'll wear no bells.

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: Why then lay one pair aside.

sp.speaker: Melan.
sp.p: But I won't dance now.

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: Why, Melancholico?

sp.speaker: Melan.
sp.p: I won't dance, unless I have one of the wrought waistcoats.

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: Why, now they have put them on.

sp.speaker: Melan.
sp.p: I care not, I won't dance else.

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: Come prithee, Cheiromantes, slip off thine again and change with him; Melancholico must have his sullen humours. So, now we want nothing but the tabor we talked of: but 'tis no matter, since he does not come, we'll sing, and so make music to ourselves. Who can tune the morris best?
sp.stage: Enter an hobby horse dancing the morris and a tabourer.
sp.p: O,The hobby horse rushes on them, and throws them all down.here they are both, here they are both.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: O my arm, my arm!

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: O my shin!

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: Ah, murrain on him; who the devil's this?

sp.speaker: Phleg.
sp.p: I have hurt my breast.

sp.speaker: Physiog.
sp.p: O the side of my face!

sp.speaker: Melan.
sp.p: A rope on you, must you throw me quite down?

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: Prithee dance the morris quietly with us: up, up, ho, and we'll dance. They 〈…〉, thee 〈…〉 over 〈…〉 them all a●●●e, 〈◊〉 Music●, and runs away with the tabourer.

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: A murrain go with you — musica, who played in the hobby-horse?

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: No, I must not tell.

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: Come then, we'll go now to barleibreak.

sp.speaker: Phleg.
sp.p: I but there's one odd: what shall he do? sit out every time?

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Yes faith, and give a reason of the other three couples meeting.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Agreed: run.
sp.stage:
They run and meet thus:
Sanguis.
Musica.
Physiognomus.
Cheiromantes.
Melancholico.
Phlegmatico.

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: A murrain on't, must I be the first man must sit out? nothing angers me but that.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Nay choler, thou'lt fret and chafe now —

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: Come choler, your reasons.

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: Why, thou and musica are met together — because — sanguine folks are most fit for music and sports. Physiognomus and Chieromantes met, because they feared we would have suspected they would have picked our pockets, if they had joined with any of us —

sp.speaker: Phys.
sp.p: We thank you choler, we shall be even with you, an't come to our turn.

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: Melancholico, and Phlegmatico joined; because one's too dry; and the other's too moist: and so they'll serve for medicines one for another: come run again: I'll be sure to catch somebody this time.
sp.stage:
They run again and meet thus.
Sanguis.
Melancholico.
Choler.
Phlegmatico
Musica.
Cheiromantes.

sp.speaker: Phys.
sp.p: I can tell you choler, you had almost missed this same time too. Well, to my task, since 'tis my luck. Sanguis and Melancholico met, because one's cold and dry, and the other's hot, and sufficiently moist: choler and phlegmatico (Have at you choler) are like a flap-dragon, or a piece of bread sopped in aquavitae, and then set afire —

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: Thank you Physiognomus.

sp.speaker: Phys.
sp.p: And musica met with Cheiromantes, because the hand in this sense, in respect of music, may most justly be called the instrument of instruments: and therefore most fitly to be coupled with it.

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: I'faith Cheiromantes you are beholding to him, he has graced you.

sp.speaker: Phys.
sp.p: Come, run again.
sp.stage:
They meet thus:
Choler.
Cheiromantes.
Sanguis.
Physiognomus.
Musica.
Phlegmatico.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: What? is't my course?

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: Hay! Melancholico will give gallant reasons.

sp.speaker: Sanguis.
sp.p: Ay, he'll be exceeding witty, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Nay, I believe he'll give incomparable reasons.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: Come on Melancholico.

sp.speaker: Phleg.
sp.p: Let's hear the first.

sp.speaker: Phys.
sp.p: He looks as if he would give profound ones.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: What? do you mean to abuse me? I'll give none. I'll play no more.

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: That's a poor put-off i'faith; either play on, or else I'll call thee blockhead as long as I know thee.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Do, do.

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: Blockhead, blockhead.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Come, you saucy ass, because you are so hot, I'll take you down: I'll propose a riddle.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Let it be a good one, and it shall be for all the reasons thou shouldst have given.

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: Yes faith, an't be a good one.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Well, take it as it is: riddle me, riddle me, what's this? It is not, and yet we see it: 'tis like a picture, and yet 'tis no picture: and it was drawn by a blind painter.

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: This is impossible.

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: Nay choler, you are too rash in your judgement — it is not, and yet we see it, — why, it may be you mean honesty, which peradventure you think is nowhere truly: but seems to be somewhere.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: No, no, your conjecture halts.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: It is not, and yet we see it? — if it had been, it is not, and yet we hear it, I could have given a reasonable conjecture.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: As how? I prithee.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Why, I could have thought it to be fame.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Indeed that had been reasonable: but you see it is not so proposed; neither could that hold with the parts that follow: well, to the next.

sp.speaker: Sanguis.
sp.p: 'Tis like a picture, and yet no picture? I'll give a very strong conjecture at that.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Let's hear it.

sp.speaker: Sanguis.
sp.p: Why, it may be a gentlewoman's face painted.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: That conjecture is plausible, but 'twill not hold with the rest. To the last.

sp.speaker: Sanguis.
sp.p: And it was drawn by a blind painter.

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: That's altogether impossible.

sp.speaker: Sanguis.
sp.p: You're too quick again, choler. I can conceive how that may be.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Sanguis.
sp.p: How? Why the painter might lose his sight after he had drawn the picture, and so be a blind painter.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Pretty, pretty, pretty.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: But you are out, sir.

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: Well, what was't now?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Nay, since you are so hot, you shan't know.

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: Nay, prithee what is't.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: No, I won't tell it.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Nay what sullenness is this? Prithee tell. What is it?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I won't.

sp.speaker: Phleg.
sp.p: A pox on't, I long to know. Prithee what is't Melancholico?

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: Come, what is't, Melancholico?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Nay, I'm a blockhead, I'm a blockhead, choler, pray what is't? your delicate wit, I doubt not can easily tell.

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: A rope of all sullen noddies: he sees every one greedy to know, and therefore out of a doggedness conceals it.

sp.speaker: Phleg.
sp.p: A rope, if he had never proposed it, it would never have angered me. Will you tell, Melancholico?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Alas, I'm a blockhead.

sp.speaker: Chairo.
sp.p: Well, we'll wait his leisure.

sp.speaker: Sanguis.
sp.p: I shall not sleep for thinking on't, if he does not tell me.

sp.speaker: Phleg.
sp.p: I shall dream on't all night.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Good Melancholico, what is't?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Alas, I'm a blockhead.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Pish, why then good blockhead, what is't?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Nay, you won't tell who danced in the hobby-horse, you.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: I' saith I will, if you'll tell this first, and swear you will not be angry with him, for throwing you down.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Nay, I'll know that first, and without all conditions.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Do 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 prithee do.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: I'll tell you 〈◊〉 in your ear, Melancholico.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Nay, he have it told openly, it concerns every one as much as me.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Why then if you would know, 'twas Phantastes; that had been at the same merry-making with me.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Phantastes! Indeed I have heard he's the only fellow in the country to dance in an hobby-horse: but he might have used his friends the humours better.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: But you'll forgive him I hope now.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: For thy sake we will.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Well. Now Melancholico, what is't?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I but musica, you shall kiss me first. They kiss.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Come on then.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Kiss me again.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Why and again.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: And again.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: And again.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Now you shall all recant the word blockhead, and say Melancholico is no blockhead: say so.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Melancholico is no blockhead.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: So musica, kiss me once more, and then I'll tell.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Why thus I do, sweet Melancholico, that art no blockhead.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p:
Well said, you little rogue. Why now I'll tell you, it is the rainbow described by Homer; but you shall have it by parts: it is not, and yet we see it, — the colours in the rain bow are not true and very colours, but only seem so to be; as I have heard Physica often say. It is like a picture, and yet is no picture, — that's manifest. And it was drawn by a blind painter, — Homer was blind and a poet, now a poet as I have heard my master say, may fitly be called a
painter; as painting may be called poesy in picture.

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: The illation is superfluous to apprehensive ears.

sp.speaker: Musica.
sp.p: I'll remember this i'faith; where are my bells, and waistcooats, and napkins? Well, now fare you well all. Exit musica.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Farewell, musica.

sp.speaker: Choler.
sp.p: Farewell, gallants; my business lies this way too.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Who goes this way?

sp.speaker: Phleg.
sp.p: That do I.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Come on then; farewell, lads.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: Fare you well: I'm glad they are all gone, I have got some what.

sp.speaker: Phys.
sp.p: What is't?

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
sp.p: The pair of bells which Melancholico would not wear.

sp.speaker: Phys.
sp.p: I protest, I never perceived, when thou didst nim them.

sp.speaker: Sang.
sp.p: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Cheiro.
